group_1.narration: <Heruka's Side>
On the day the Mongolian threat was@held at bay for the time being,@I took the urn that held the ashes of all@those who had died in my hometown@and spread them on the ground.
The ashes will return to the soil@and become a source of nourishment@for those blue flowers.
The flowers today are somehow@more beautiful than usual.
Ever since that night…
Perhaps it's all because my wish made the@Rakshasi disappear from everyone's memory…
The nunnery now has been known@for ages as a refuge for war orphans…@Everyone's view of it has changed.
It seems that all the things related to the@Rakshasi have been altered in a chain reaction.@The very idea of "Junior Nuns," and Lord Jataka…@All of it has been forgotten.
The records of Rakshasi still remain in@ancient literature and scriptures, however.
I've only erased the "memories" of the Rakshasi…@The Magical Girls at the heart of this conflict.

group_1.textRight: Lady Herukaaa! I brought you some butter tea!@Please enjoy.
Ooh, you have such good etiquette!

group_1.narration: Everyone's attitude towards me has changed@dramatically, but I've gotten over it.
I'm determined to live as a Rakshasi@until my last breath.
And along with that…Rabi and her friends chose@to stay at the nunnery for a little while longer.

group_1.textLeft: You mind if we stick around a li'l more?
I wanna find out more about the Rakshasi.

group_1.textRight: Well…everything else is going as recorded…
Ah, erm… Ahaha…@This story, we mean.
…Heruka, are you happy with being@a Magical Girl?
…You're aware?

group_1.textLeft: I wasn't told, but I do understand.
I was given great power. It's only natural@to assume it comes at a price.

group_1.textRight: It may be heavier than you think…
But even so…you have no regrets?

group_1.narration: I felt very reassured to have these Rakshasi…@No, these veteran Magical Girls by my side.
But…there also came farewells.

group_1.textRight: …So far so good.

group_1.textLeft: Yeah, but…@I wish you could stay a little longer.

group_1.narration: After the nunnery's restoration was complete,@Dolma said she was leaving.
She wanted to join the Order of the White Hill…@One of the leading religious groups here in Tibet.

group_1.textRight: If they allow me into their ranks, I'll be sure@to see if they can lend aid to the nunnery.
It was fun to make our own way, but…@[chara:833300:lipSynch_0][wait:1.5][chara:833300:cheek_0][chara:833300:face_mtn_ex_030.exp3.json][chara:833300:lipSynch_1]It was hard all the same.

group_1.textLeft: But why does it have to be you, Dolma…?

group_1.textRight: What, you think you can do it, Sleepyhead?@Or Deki? Or the other kids?

group_1.textLeft: Good point…@We don't have anyone else…

group_1.textRight: I'm just the right person for the job.
And…I think this is the best way for me@to help you.

group_1.textLeft: I mean, I've been the one getting help@all this time, so…please take this.

group_1.textRight: …What is it?

group_1.textLeft: It's a shell leaf manuscript the Lama gave me,@to help me learn the Mongolian language.

group_1.textRight: You mean from that coward who ran away?

group_1.textLeft: Still…it's helped me so much...@So I think it'll help you, too.

group_1.textRight: …You think me learning more about Mongolia@will make me change my mind?

group_1.textLeft: I think that's up to you, Dolma.

group_1.textRight: Maybe so…@Whatever, I'll take it.
Well…I better get going. But you'll tag along@with me for a little while, yeah?

group_1.textLeft: …Hey, Dolma, are you still scared of the night?

group_1.textRight: I am. I really am, but…
I'll get past it myself.

group_1.narration: We left our home together,@walking side by side down a hill@we had never gone down before.
Our surroundings were unfamiliar,@and yet they didn't feel any different@from the landscapes I knew.
If anything, with the grass and leaves@gleaming brightly under the sun…@It was all so beautiful.
We spoke of memories, joyful and a little sad,@holding hands as we walked down that long hill.
"I believe in hope," I thought,@"and I will continue to show my devotion."
I believed that as long as we never gave up,@no matter what failures we faced,@no matter what mistakes we made,@we would keep going…
It really was a wonderful thing.
I held Dolma's hand tightly,@as if to prove that even if we were separated,@we would always be connected…
And I swore to myself that I would put an end@to this war and keep Dolma safe.
